div.l: Vppon his argument / of herbergage
Wele seyde Salamon / in his langage
Ne bryng nat eủery man / in to thyn hous
For herborowyng by nyght is ꝑperilous
Wele aught a man / avised for to be
Whom that he brought / in to his pryuyte
Y pᵃray to god so yeve sorwe and care
Yf eủer seth I hight hogge of ware
Herde neủer I a Myller / better sette a werke
He hadde a Iape / of malice in the derke
But god forbede / that we stynte here
And therfore if ye voiche safe to here
A tale of me that am a pore man
I wille yow telle as eủer I kan
A litel Iape that fel in oure Citee
Oure hoost answerde / and I gᵃraunt it the
Now telle on Roger / and loke þᵗat it be good
For many a pasty hastow laat blood
And many a Iakke of Dover hastow solde
That hath be twyes hoot / and twies colde
Of many a pilgryme hastow cristes curs
For of thy ꝑpersely yet fare they the wurs
That they han eten / in thyn stuble goos
For in thy shoppe is many a flie loos
Now telle on gentel Roger by thy name
But yet I pᵃray the be not wroth for game
A man may say full sooth / in game and pley
Thow seyst ful sooth quod Roger / by my fey
But suche pley / quade pley / as the flemmyng seith
And herry bailly by thy feith
Be thow nat wrooth or we departe here
Thoughet Thought Thoughe that my tale / be of an hostelere
But natheles I wille nat telle it yit
But or we departe I wis thow shall be quytte
And ther with alle loughe and made good chere
And seide his tale / as ye shulle after here
A Prentise whilom dwelled in oure Citee
Of a crafte of vitaillers was he
